ERROR_LP_EMPTY: Error! There is no Linear Program defined.
SIMPLE_EXAMPLE: The example below and the data section that can be used to test its resolution are from Modeling Language GNU MathProg, Appendix E.
DATA_SECTION: Data section of the example below:
DATA_SECTION_DATA: set I := Seattle    San-Diego;</br>set J := New-York    Chicago Topeka;</br></br>param A := Seattle    350</br>      San-Diego    600;</br></br>param B := New-York   325</br>      Chicago    300</br>      Topeka    275;</br></br>param C :       New-York    Chicago    Topeka := </br>       Seattle    0.225    0.153    0.162</br>       San-Diego    0.225    0.162    0.126;</br>
TIP1: Define the Linear Programming Model in the Objective and Constraints sections, as shown in the example below.
TIP2: A constraint can not end with COMMA ',', thus ',\' means that the constraint continues in the next line.
TIP4: Variables must belong to one of the following sets: $\mathbb{B}$ or $\{0,1\}$, $\mathbb{R}$, $\mathbb{R}^{+}$, $\mathbb{Z}$, $\mathbb{Z}^{+}$ and $\mathbb{N}$.
TIP5: The MathProg code can be solved by pressing the 'Solve MathProg' button. In this tool, it is solved using the glpk.js library, which is an implementation in javascript of the GLPK (GNU Linear Programming Kit), that can also be used to solve the problem (you have to fill the data section to solve it). Besides, the GLPK package offers commands/methods to convert a code in MathProg format to the following formats: CPLEX LP, MPS fixed, MPS free and GLPK.
COPY_DATA_SECTION: Copy to Data Section in MathProg Code
